Robert Lucente wrote:
> Thanks for the help.
> 
> I am a newbie to Java/JUnit. I am going to begin by examining the suggestion
> in Friday, January 20, 2006 1:41 PM about setUp/tearDown.
> 
> "rarely the best one"
> 
> It all depend on how you define "best".
> 
> If I am running tests on my PC and don't have a lot of time to delve into
> the memory problem, why not add that 1 GB of memory to the PC and meet the
> deliverable date ?

This is precisely the kind of thinking that leads to dissatisfied 
customers. Are /they/ going to just pop in 1 GB RAM to run your 
software? A memory problem in testing often means a memory problem in 
the production code.

> If this is an exercise to learn the technology, then I would investigate
> setUp/tearDown, lazy loading and so on.

I think it's one of our basic responsibilities as programmers to take 
reasonable precautions against writing software that arbitrarily sucks 
up large amounts of memory. I assume, of course, that we intend our 
customers to let our software run for days, weeks, months at a time.
